required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: CtDNA as a Novel Biomarker of Treatment Efficacy in Patients With Ovarian Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: Circulating Tumor DNA as a Novel Molecular Marker of Treatment Efficacy to Guide Targeted Maintenance Therapy for Patients With High Grade Serous Ovarian Cancer

lead_sponsor.agency: Xinhua Hospital, Shanghai Jiao Tong University School of Medicine

clinical_study.source: Xinhua Hospital, Shanghai Jiao Tong University School of Medicine

brief_summary.textblock: This study is a prospective observational clinical trial. Patients who were diagnosed and treated for the first time were enrolled and their surgical pathology was confirmed to be high-grade serous ovarian cancer. At the same time, these patients will receive first-line maintenance treatment with PARP inhibitors after traditional chemotherapy. During the trial period, patients' plasma will be collected before surgery, after chemotherapy, during targeted maintenance therapy, and during disease progression, and ctDNA-specific genomes will be detected, and clinical data will be collected over the same period. It is expected that specific ctDNA can be used to predict the efficacy of PARP inhibitors in patients with ovarian cancer, and to detect the recurrence of the disease early.

primary_outcome.time_frame: about 36 months after using PARP inhibitors
primary_outcome.description: To determine the different prognosis of patients after using the PARP inhibitor for first-line maintenance treatment, at the same time, the plasma will be collected and tested for ctDNA before using the PARP inhibitor, during use and when the disease is progressing.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: about over 5 years after using PARP inhibitors

secondary_outcome.description: To evaluate the general response of patients with ovarian cancer to PARP inhibitors

arm_group.arm_group_label: patients using olaparib combined with bevacizumab

study_pop.textblock: Newly-diagnosed and treated patients with high-grade serous ovarian cancer who will receive PARP inhibitors as first-line maintenance therapy after surgery and traditional chemotherapy.
